docs.abstract: A critique of the president's speech, revisited.
docs.snippet: A critique of the president's speech, revisited.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait had an interesting response to the criticisms that both David Frum and I lodged against the President's Osawatomie speech. We both suggested that the president offered a plausible description of the middle class's recent woes, coupled with a weak and potentially counterproductive prescription for how to actually address them. To this, Chait basically conceded the relative thinness of the president's opportunity agenda, and then went on to argue that it doesn't really matter because the Republicans are worse:
docs.abstract: A critique of the president's speech, revisited.
docs.snippet: A critique of the president's speech, revisited.

headline.main: A New York-Centric Bookstore Is Reborn, in Pixels

docs.abstract: The Day: The old New York Bound bookstore has been reinvented as a Web site. Also, what City Room is reading in other newspapers and blogs.
docs.snippet: The Day: The old New York Bound bookstore has been reinvented as a Web site. Also, what City Room is reading in other newspapers and blogs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, not so long ago, there was a bookstore that was the best place - often the only place - to find anything on just about everything that had been written, photographed or sketched in regard to this city.

headline.main: A New York-Centric Bookstore Is Reborn, in Pixels

docs.abstract: The Day: The old New York Bound bookstore has been reinvented as a Web site. Also, what City Room is reading in other newspapers and blogs.
docs.snippet: The Day: The old New York Bound bookstore has been reinvented as a Web site. Also, what City Room is reading in other newspapers and blogs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Confusion Follows Claim That Corzine Knew of Funds Transfer  |  A Senate hearing into the collapse of MF Global was thrown into confusion on Tuesday after a main witness implied that Jon S. Corzine, its former chief executive, knew the firm had been misusing customer funds, an accusation that could not be substantiated.

headline.main: Despite 2 Floods, a Business Decides to Stay Put

docs.abstract: Two business owners explain their decision to stay on in an uncertain location.
docs.snippet: Two business owners explain their decision to stay on in an uncertain location.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, we published a case study about two disaster-frazzled entrepreneurs seemingly in need of some of the calming supplemental holistic health services - yoga and massage - that they offer at Pulling Down the Moon, a Chicago business that was hit by two floods within a year.

headline.main: Despite 2 Floods, a Business Decides to Stay Put

docs.abstract: But what if there's a third flood? "We would break our lease and say sayonara," said one owner.
docs.snippet: But what if there's a third flood? "We would break our lease and say sayonara," said one owner.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Donald Berwick makes a compelling case about the harm caused by partisan demagoguery and about the need for health care professionals to accelerate reforms.

headline.seo: Advice From Dr. Berwick, a Health Care Visionary
headline.main: Candid Advice From a Health Care Visionary
headline.print_headline: Candid Advice From a Health Care Visionary

docs.abstract: Editorial asserts that Dr Donald Berwick, who was blocked by Republicans from serving a full term as the administrator of the agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid, makes a compelling case about the harm caused by partisan demagoguery and about the need for health care professionals to accelerate reforms.
docs.snippet: Dr. Donald Berwick makes a compelling case about the harm caused by partisan demagoguery and about the need for health care professionals to accelerate reforms.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill signed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo secures patients’ ability to fill prescriptions locally and is expected to help small pharmacies compete with mail-order providers in the state of New York.

headline.seo: Mandatory-Mail-Order Pharmacy Plans Banned by New State Law
headline.main: New Law Bans Mail-Order Drug Mandates
headline.print_headline: New Law Bans Mail-Order Drug Mandates

docs.abstract: New York State Gov Andrew M Cuomo signs bill that bars insurers or employers from forcing patients to use mail-order plans for prescription drugs, except for plans negotiated by unions.
docs.snippet: A bill signed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo secures patients’ ability to fill prescriptions locally and is expected to help small pharmacies compete with mail-order providers in the state of New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal and state subsidies have taken a hit from budget cuts, forcing parents to find other arrangements to stay employed.

headline.seo: Child Care Subsidies Drop When Families Need Them Most
headline.main: Aid for Child Care Drops When It Is Needed Most
headline.print_headline: Subsidies for Child Care Keep Dwindling When Families Need Them Most

docs.abstract: Government subsidy for child care, a mix of federal and state funds that reimburses child care providers on behalf of low income families, has eroded over the years by inflation, growing need, and state budget cuts; poor parents across the nation have been left struggling to find other arrangements in order to stay employed.
docs.snippet: Federal and state subsidies have taken a hit from budget cuts, forcing parents to find other arrangements to stay employed.
